turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about EndeavourOS.
turn.2: Since RebornOS, another Antergos derivative, already took the road Antergos travelled, the team came up with the idea to create an almost close to Arch system with a friendly and supportive community at its core.
turn.3: What is the most important feature of EndeavourOS?
turn.4: This meant discarding preinstalled apps and packages, like a email client or an office suite from the repository and making the terminal the visible heart of the system again.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: This plan received mixed reviews within the community, especially the exclusion of Pamac, a popular GUI wrapper for Pacman the packagemanager for Arch-Linux, in the repo.
turn.7: What is the most important fact in this article?
turn.8: The main idea is to give the user freedom to create a system to their specific needs and getting to learn the system by installing the desired packages themselves, with the help from the friendly and warm community.
turn.9: What else did you find interesting?
turn.10: With their new philosophy, the team has made a conscious choice to target a specific audience that either already knew Arch Linux, but wanted a fast and simple install, or the "distro-hoppers" who already had some Linux knowledge but wanted to explore Arch Linux without the technical install procedure of the base distribution.
turn.11: Does it have any other features?
turn.12: By not shipping a GUI package manager by default, the team is convinced that the user will be more aware of what they are installing and therefore have more control on the installed system.
